repnme.cdata!: Madagascar - Second Health Sector Support Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second Health Sector
            Support Project for Madagascar were as follows: outcomes
            were satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            moderate, the Bank performance was moderately satisfactory,
            and the Borrower performance was satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: the project was able to reach its goals
            despite all obstacles thanks to the flexibility used by the
            World Bank and Government's team in its implementation.
            This flexibility helped to respond to the cyclones and to
            evolving needs. This flexibility also allowed quick
            reallocations of resources from activities funded by other
            sources to others that were not. The decentralization of the
            activities financed by the project, and particularly the
            technical assistance offered to the deconcentrated levels of
            the ministry also allowed a smoother implementation of
            activities and the achievement of the project development
            objective (PDO). However, technical assistance to the
            central level is also needed to ensure a sustainable
            development of the health system. Public-private
            partnerships in the health sector can be a useful tool to
            provide quality health services; however, enough resources
            need to be provided to ensure that the cost of this
            provision is covered. To increase service utilization it is
            important to make sure that all causes of non-utilization
            are dealt with. This project only aimed at improving
            geographical access by trying to build new facilities.
            However, the main cause of non-utilization of health
            services has always been their cost.

repnme.cdata!: Madagascar - Second Health Sector Support Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Health Sector Support Project
            is a proposed supplemental credit of SDR 12.3 million (US$
            18.0 million equivalent) to Development Credit No. 3302-MAG
            (Second Health Sector Support Project) for Madagascar to
            cover the increased costs of meeting the project's
            development targets following a series of unforeseen
            circumstances including natural disasters and socio-economic
            upheaval as well as political conflict and reform.

repnme.cdata!: Madagascar - Second Health Sector Support Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Health Sector Support Project
            aims to improve the quality of, and access to primary health
            services, especially in rural areas. There are five project
            components. The first finances civil works for health
            centers and district hospitals, re-equipping newly
            constructed or rehabilitated health facilities; and carries
            out studies, trains personnel, provides medicines; supports
            supervision activities, decentralized health
            administrations, sanitation activities; and helps maintain
            buildings, equipment, and vehicles. The second component
            finances transport and other logistical expenditures, drugs
            and insecticides, equipment, studies, and training to
            diagnose, prevent, treat, and monitor malaria, tuberculosis,
            plague, and schistosomiasis. The third component funds
            information, education, and communication efforts to improve
            reproductive health service delivery; training to raise
            standards in health interventions like child survival and
            safe motherhood; and prevention campaigns to improve
            STD/HIV/AIDS services, particularly among prostitutes and
            other groups at risk. The fourth component provides a
            package of institutional strengthening and child treatment
            support to enable the health ministry to enhance the
            effectiveness of nutrition programs and to develop a
            multi-sectoral operational nutrition information system. The
            fifth component finances reform by improving sector
            coordination; increasing service coverage, financial access,
            and equity; and enhancing efficiency.
